description: An iconic open-air flea market located on the former Dry Bridge (Mshrali Khidi) and adjacent Dedaena and 9 March parks. Known as 'the market of memories,' it is Tbilisi's premier destination for Soviet-era memorabilia, antiques, vintage items, and contemporary Georgian art. The market emerged after the Soviet Union's collapse in the 1990s when locals began selling their possessions to make ends meet, though its roots trace back to the 1950s. The name comes from its location on a bridge over a dried-up arm of the Kura River.
highlights: Extensive Soviet memorabilia including war medals, military ID books, propaganda posters, Stalin and Lenin items, hammer and sickle symbols, and Soviet-issue film cameras
Eclectic mix of genuine antiques: World War II medals, ornate swords, vintage radio sets, enamel engravings, silver jewelry, and 19th-century items from the Caucasus and Central Asia
Vintage collectibles: old rubles, coins, matchboxes, stamps, vinyl records, CDs, Russian language books, old maps, and caviar tins
Contemporary art section with local artists displaying paintings, graphics, and sculptures, many working on-site with easels and canvases hung on specially made stands
Traditional Georgian handicrafts: feltwork, pottery, traditional embroideries, crochet and knitted items, kantsi drinking horns, and panduri instruments
Antique dishware, furniture, cameras, and various ephemera from Georgia's days as a Socialist Republic
Open-air art exhibition where visitors can engage directly with Georgian artists and craftspeople
Unique historical items including pre-Soviet pieces and artifacts from throughout the Caucasus region
tips: TIMING: Visit on Saturdays or Sundays between 11:00 AM and 4:00 PM for the liveliest atmosphere with maximum vendors. Avoid Mondays when the market is only half full. Arrive early for first pick of items and to avoid afternoon crowds

BARGAINING: Haggling is expected and part of the culture. Start at one-third of the asking price. Prices are often higher for tourists. Speaking Russian may help get better deals. Approach bargaining with friendliness and respect
PAYMENT: Cash only - bring Georgian Lari in small denominations to facilitate easier transactions. No credit cards accepted

AUTHENTICITY: Be cautious about reproductions versus genuine antiques. Some vendors sell modern replicas (like shiny Stalin flasks also found in museum gift shops). If you're a serious collector, inquire about provenance before purchasing
WEATHER: The market may not operate if weather is bad, as it's entirely outdoors
LANGUAGE: Vendors may speak Georgian, Russian, and limited English. Russian language skills helpful for better prices
RESPECT: Remember that some booths are run by locals selling their own possessions to make ends meet. Be polite and considerate
EXPLORATION: Take time to explore all three areas - the bridge itself, Dedaena Park, and 9 March Park - each has different specialties

PRICE RANGES: Prices are generally rock bottom and can be haggled even lower. Small items like Soviet pins and medals: 5-20 GEL; Vintage cameras and larger collectibles: 30-100+ GEL; Artwork varies widely based on artist and size
NEARBY COMBINATION: After shopping, relax in adjacent Dedaena or 9 March parks. The market's central location makes it easy to walk to other attractions
vibe: A nostalgic treasure hunt through Soviet history meets vibrant local art scene. The atmosphere is eclectic and somewhat chaotic, with vendors displaying everything from genuine historical artifacts to quirky knick-knacks on blankets and makeshift tables. Artists work alongside memorabilia dealers, creating a unique blend of past and present Georgian culture. The market has an authentic, unpolished character - it's not overly touristy despite its popularity. Weekend visits feel more energetic with crowds of both locals and tourists hunting for bargains, while weekdays are quieter and more intimate. There's a sense of living history as you browse through items that tell stories of Georgia's Soviet past, mixed with the creative energy of contemporary Georgian artists. The bargaining culture adds an interactive, social element to shopping. Overall, it's an atmospheric experience that offers both cultural insight and the thrill of discovery, whether you're seeking Soviet kitsch, genuine antiques, or original artwork. The market serves as both a window into Georgia's complex 20th-century history and a showcase for its modern creative spirit.
